text:
Hello frenz!

The company I work for is being merged into a larger company of about double the size. Since I’ve been heading up our content team for the last four years, and since our content performs so well, I’ve been asked to think about where / how content should sit in the new organization. Obviously, I don’t have final say or anything, but I am trying to come up with different structures that might be possible. This is a wonderful opportunity to influence the content culture in the new organization, get resources and stuff in place I’ve never been able to before, and carve my own path without having to go the traditional people manager route.

That being said…for those of you in organizations *OVER 150 people*, I’d love to know how your content teams are structured:
Specifically:
• What is your company size vs content team size?
• Do you have a specific content function or are you more embedded in the wider marketing team?
• What is the hierarchy or org flow?
• Is there any centralization or how do you work cross functionally between other departments like customer success / education, product marketing / sales enablement, design, comms, etc.?

text:
Hey everyone! Anyone have tips for managers on better 1:1s?

In my experience, I always _hope_ that 1:1s will be an opportunity for my team to bring up goals, issues, etc., that they don’t feel like they can ask me elsewhere, and that they’ll also provide space for their professional development. In practice, it seems they always become quick checkins, work sessions, or something where I end up going through a list of to-dos that I needed to talk to them about anyway. In other words, it seems to peter out unless I take charge.

Anyway. :sweat_smile:  Any advice for giving direct reports clarity around 1:1s and ownership of the meetings? Is there a better way to make them useful to everyone and not a chore?

elements.text:
Hey everyone! Anyone have tips for managers on better 1:1s?

In my experience, I always
hope

that 1:1s will be an opportunity for my team to bring up goals, issues, etc., that they don’t feel like they can ask me elsewhere, and that they’ll also provide space for their professional development. In practice, it seems they always become quick checkins, work sessions, or something where I end up going through a list of to-dos that I needed to talk to them about anyway. In other words, it seems to peter out unless I take charge.

Anyway.
Any advice for giving direct reports clarity around 1:1s and ownership of the meetings? Is there a better way to make them useful to everyone and not a chore?

text:
In some of the proDev material we've authored recently,  we've advised to position the 1:1 as "purposeful small talk"

It's a space where you talk about every that's NOT work/checklists. Your goal is to probe then listen, prying at topics surrounding:

~ how's the home life going? Esp if the person is remote/virtualized thanks to the pandemic
~ what hobbies are they into (a pathway towards "get talking about your passions and what makes you tick outside of executing work")
~ fantasize about the next year re: career, re: life

You can also let them choose the 1:1 time using Calendly or similar tools, so long as they remember schedule one at least X times per Y.

The goal here is not to set up this formal "Professional Development Time" space, but rather a space to build a relationship outside of the worklife, to build trust, to circle around the more emotional or psychological things that make someone happy/less happy.

text: (As the manager, keep diligent notes and bring up salient topics in future 1:1s — especially things not related to work)

elements.text: (As the manager, keep diligent notes and bring up salient topics in future 1:1s — especially things not related to work)

text:
I always start the 1:1 process with new hires the same way - scheduled it and include this in the meeting invite:

> This is your meeting. I will always have a few ideas of things we can chat about, but ultimately you are running this meeting and it’s your time to get what you need from me. 
> 
> For example:
> Gut check: How do you feel about things? Work, life, whatever.
> Short-term goals: Check in on logistics, deadlines, etc.
> What’s in your way, preventing you from being successful? Escalate anything you think I can help with so you can focus on doing your job.
> Long-term goals: What can you do this week/month/quarter to hit those? How can I help?
> Ideas for team improvements: What processes can we make better?

elements.text: I always start the 1:1 process with new hires the same way - scheduled it and include this in the meeting invite:

This is your meeting. I will always have a few ideas of things we can chat about, but ultimately you are running this meeting and it’s your time to get what you need from me. 

For example:
Gut check: How do you feel about things? Work, life, whatever.
Short-term goals: Check in on logistics, deadlines, etc.
What’s in your way, preventing you from being successful? Escalate anything you think I can help with so you can focus on doing your job.
Long-term goals: What can you do this week/month/quarter to hit those? How can I help?
Ideas for team improvements: What processes can we make better?

text: In my first one at this company my boss had a list of questions about my working style, what frustrates me and why, how i like to receive feedback, and such, that ended up being super productive (for instance, i said i'd like more feedback even just a casual thanks or good job because i felt isolated and he's made a big effort to do that). Since that one, in our regular meetings he asks "whats going well and why" and "whats not going well and why" and those usually lead to good conversations about my role, what i need, company issues, etc. Julie Zhuo had a great post on medium iirc about one on ones and managing your relationship with your employees that I can't find right now but I recommend trying to dig it up

text:
Wow, thanks all. Super helpful!

Great questions <@URAV154AV>, thanks for sharing.

<@U0113AV4895> I like the idea of having a sort of kickoff to learn more about the person’s work style, etc., and then just making an open floor for future meetings.

<@U01AHL8AGBB> I often feel like my team has already talked to me about more small-talky kind of things, so then it feels like there’s not as much need for life updates. But it’s a good reminder to be interested/checking in/remembering what my team tells me is going on with them.

My team also craves more time to be heads down and fewer extra meetings (we are a lot of introverts!) so I don’t want them to feel forced into casually talking.

But anyway, thanks! These are great ideas. :slightly_smiling_face:

elements.text:
Wow, thanks all. Super helpful!

Great questions
, thanks for sharing.
I like the idea of having a sort of kickoff to learn more about the person’s work style, etc., and then just making an open floor for future meetings.

I often feel like my team has already talked to me about more small-talky kind of things, so then it feels like there’s not as much need for life updates. But it’s a good reminder to be interested/checking in/remembering what my team tells me is going on with them.

My team also craves more time to be heads down and fewer extra meetings (we are a lot of introverts!) so I don’t want them to feel forced into casually talking.

But anyway, thanks! These are great ideas.

text: The Julie Zhou piece specifically speaks to that "getting to know your employees" step to learn about their style (and share yours as well), i really can't recommend it enough. I'll keep looking for it :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
:thinking_face: I'm assuming that we're talking about direct/org reports here.  For me, I tend to view meetings with reports as a ~biweekly chance to make it clear to them that they and their happiness matter.  So, in terms of rules of engagement, it's a meeting where:
1. I'm never late
2. I'm never distracted
3. I almost never cancel or reschedule
4. They own the agenda -- it's their meeting, but I will fill in the gaps with questions that have a purpose, if they don't have anything they want to cover. (IOW, if they want to discuss something tactical that meeting, it's their dime)
Even though I view it as their meeting, though, I do have an agenda, which is that I'm looking to shift morale problem detection as far left as possible -- to get a bead on stuff that might make them unhappy ideally before even _they_ figure out that they're unhappy.  (A common adage I offer is, "I can't promise that you'll always enjoy the work you're doing, but I can promise that you'll always be on an actionable path to enjoying it more.")  So I have 4 main pieces of information that I want to solicit:
1. What's happening with your workload and stress level?
2. Do you have any concerns about what's happening in your day to day, or more existential ones?
3. Do you have questions about the state of the business where you don't have line of sight, but I do?
4. What's your enjoyment level of the things you're doing day-to-day/week-to-week?
I won't just ask those questions, though.  Otherwise, it becomes a rote checklist.  Instead, I'll ask variants, designed to provoke non-rehearsed responses.  So "what are you enjoying or not enjoying" becomes "hey, you just kicked off that new customer experience program, and I imagine you were operating with a little more uncertainty than you're used to -- was that uncertainty exhilarating, terrifying, or a little of each?"

So "what are you enjoying or not enjoying" becomes "hey, you just kicked off that new customer experience program, and I imagine you were operating with a little more uncertainty than you're used to -- was that uncertainty exhilarating, terrifying, or a little of each?"

text: Apart from that, we're always talking through quarterly goals and progress against those in a blameless kind of way, which grounds things a bit and lets me align org goals with everyone's work

elements.text: Apart from that, we're always talking through quarterly goals and progress against those in a blameless kind of way, which grounds things a bit and lets me align org goals with everyone's work

text: Anyway, YMMV, but that's the backbone of a formula that's served me pretty well for the last going on 10 years, and now I feel old

text:
That's freaking awesome! Congrats.

I can share insight from my previous position as Head of Global Content Marketing at Eventbrite, where we were deeply integrated across the business and collaborated with PR/Comms, PMM, CS, Design, and even R&D.

• Company size vs team size: ~1,500 vs 7 FTE + 2 agencies and pool of contract writers
• Specific function or embedded: Embedded or, more accurately, fully integrated. 
• Hierarchy/org flow: Global (lead + 2 FTE + agency) reported Brand and then Growth. EU (lead + agency for translation/localization) reported to EU marketing head, LATAM (lead only) reported to LATAM marketing head, NA (lead only) reported to NA marketing head, APAC (lead only) reported to APAC marketing head. All regional leads dotted lined into me. 
• Centralization or cross-functionally: This is super hard to explain without writing a novel to cover the numerable nuances. The gist is that my team produced globally-applicable content and oversaw a complex content atomization and production process that pumped out a ton of high-quality content that supported/partnered with multiple business units.
Hope this is useful. Ultimately, your decision will depend on the business goals and the structure of the merged org. I'd be more than happy to chat, offer more details and alternative perspectives, as well as share what I'd do differently today.

Company size vs team size: ~1,500 vs 7 FTE + 2 agencies and pool of contract writers
Specific function or embedded: Embedded or, more accurately, fully integrated.

Hierarchy/org flow: Global (lead + 2 FTE + agency) reported Brand and then Growth. EU (lead + agency for translation/localization) reported to EU marketing head, LATAM (lead only) reported to LATAM marketing head, NA (lead only) reported to NA marketing head, APAC (lead only) reported to APAC marketing head. All regional leads dotted lined into me.

Centralization or cross-functionally: This is super hard to explain without writing a novel to cover the numerable nuances. The gist is that my team produced globally-applicable content and oversaw a complex content atomization and production process that pumped out a ton of high-quality content that supported/partnered with multiple business units.

Hope this is useful. Ultimately, your decision will depend on the business goals and the structure of the merged org. I'd be more than happy to chat, offer more details and alternative perspectives, as well as share what I'd do differently today.

text: This is really helpful, Amanda and Nik! Do you use any tools to measure "opportunities influenced" or is this just measured by word of mouth?

elements.text: This is really helpful, Amanda and Nik! Do you use any tools to measure "opportunities influenced" or is this just measured by word of mouth?

text: We don’t, far as I know. That kind of goes beyond our purview (since we’re focused on driving organic traffic, not much else). But I’m sure some of the lead gen folks on the client side we work with might have some such metric.
